page.title: 18Sewage Works
page.content: The Seamer Sewage Works,built in 1947, serves 17 villages around Scarborough. The sewage is pumped to the works.In 1970 the works were extended to take 1,000,000 gallons of sewage a day.It is taken to the top of the inlet by an Archemedes screw pump.It goes through a grit trap where grit settles and is taken away,through a shredder then to the primary settlement tanks.The sewage flows into a tank where solids sink to an embanked bottom,where the liquid is pumped into tanks filled with rocks with bacteria on.The sewage is pumped onto them,the effluence is eaten and the water containing NO3 flows to humus tanks which filters more impurities.It goes through a clarifier (mesh and gravel) where the last impurities are filtered.Finally water comes out and is pumped into streams.The works serve 40,000 people.
